series.series.name: PLUS: YACHT RACING -- SOLO TRANS-ATLANTIC RACE

abstract.p: English sailor Ellen MacArthur sails into Newport, RI, to win Class 1 monohull division of Europe 1 New Man singlehanded trans-Atlantic race (S)

block.p: Ending over three decades of national frustration, the 23-year-old English sailor Ellen MacArthur sailed into Newport, R.I., early yesterday to win the Class 1 monohull division of the Europe 1 New Man singlehanded trans-Atlantic race, which started from Plymouth, England, on June 4.
MacArthur is the youngest winner in the race's 40-year history, and the first British sailor to win since Geoffrey Williams in 1968.

Ending over three decades of national frustration, the 23-year-old English sailor Ellen MacArthur sailed into Newport, R.I., early yesterday to win the Class 1 monohull division of the Europe 1 New Man singlehanded trans-Atlantic race, which started from Plymouth, England, on June 4.
MacArthur is the youngest winner in the race's 40-year history, and the first British sailor to win since Geoffrey Williams in 1968.

In a cool northerly breeze, MacArthur steered her 60-foot Kingfisher across the finish line at 6:21 a.m. in Newport to complete the race in 14 days 23 hours 11 minutes. Kingfisher was one of 19 Open 60's in the field, three of which were dismasted and forced to retire soon after the start.
''I was really, really nervous before the start, but I got ahead quickly and gained confidence,'' she said.
PLUS: YACHT RACING -- SOLO TRANS-ATLANTIC RACE
